description: 1967 Mercedes-Benz 300SE;

This is a true find.   Zero rust.  83k original miles.  Original Paint.  New fuel system and tank.  Brand new air suspension.  There weren't a lot of these produced and to find one in this condition is very rare.

History:  Originally bought in 1968 in San Francisco by Dr. Clifton Wright of Lake Tahoe, CA.  Sold to Roger Schaefer of San Luis Obispo in 1984.  Roger moved to Coeur D Alene, ID in 1988 and parked the car in storage in 1989.  It was in need of new air bellows as they were no longer holding air overnight.  Long story short, Roger was getting old and knew he wasn't going to be able to work on the car like he hoped so he drained the gas and fogged the cylinders.  I met Roger in 2014 and he gave me a sales pitch that made me buy the car from him impulsively.  I am the 3rd owner to this day.  I told him I would get it running and in proper order and we'll cruise it around.  I did get it running and the air suspension dialed in, but Roger is no longer mobile.

Work Done: I disassembled the fuel system, cleaned it out, and had the tank relined.  Put in a new battery and it started up like it was just turned off yesterday.  25 years!!  The air suspension was fixed with all 4 new bellows as well as air control valves.  The longest I have let it sit without starting it is 3 weeks and it holds the air the entire time.  I decided to keep replacing parts so most of the belts and hoses are new.  This car should run worry free for a long time.

Interior: The interior has been completely redone in original Mercedes leather to exactly match the original.  The original was green and wasn't in bad shape but definitely showed a little wear.  I originally intended to keep this car so I had the interior done in a saddle tan color  Again, it is EXACTLY the same as the original, but in a better (to me) color.  The carpet and floor mats were reproduced as well.

Exterior: The paint is original and in pretty good shape.  The top shows a little sign of oxidation.  Not sure if it would buff out.  I have only washed it a few times as it has mostly sat in the garage minus a few trips to the office.  The hood and trunk show no signs of oxidation.  There is ZERO rust.  The window seals are a little dry.  If I were going to keep the car, I would most likely replace them for proper aesthetics.  They are available from the Classic center.  Not 100%, but I think I was quoted about $200 for all glass seals.  There are a few small dimples in the chrome bumpers that can easily be fixed.  The passenger door has a small dent.  Roger told me the car was bumped in a parking lot.  I haven't addressed anything on the exterior.

Parts: I have the original manuals and the Becker Grand Prix radio.  I also lots of spare gaskets and hoses that Roger had bought when he parked the car in 1989.  As I said, he had intended to redo everything whether it needed it or not so he bought every possible spare part he though he might need.  I have used a lot of them but I will include what's left in the sale.

Overall:  I'd say the car is an 8/10.  The interior is probably the nicest on any 300SE on the planet.  It runs like new.  The air suspension, which is the most costly to update is done.  If want an absolutely flawless show car, it would just need a small amount of attention on the exterior.

280SL.  Very good condition.  I am the third owner.  I have owned the car since 1988.  Has always been kept in a garage.  Has third seat, air conditioning and an 8 track tape player. I have all original service books and owners manual as well as a list of mercedes dealers as they existed in July of 1969. This car has never been in an accident.

A true preservation car with all original interior including her Makassar ebony wood trim and Roser leather upholstery, all holding up wonderfully. Of the already rare W109 chassis cars, only those made between 1965 and 1967 came with the M189* all-alloy engine. With just 2,365 produced during this period, this is the rarest variant.
Fully serviced including ice-cold A/C and highly advanced for-the-time pneumatic-suspension. 67,448 miles.
*This is essentially the same engine as used in the late series 300SL roadster (the sister car to the Gullwing)
1970 Mercedes-Benz 300SEL 6.3
“6.3 is a Collector Car”
4dr Sedan 8-cyl. 6329cc/300hp Bosch FI
Exterior Color: Copper
Interior Color: Cognac Leather
Transmission: 4-Speed Automatic transmission

The 1968-1972 Mercedes-Benz 300 SEL 6.3 holds a unique place in auto history. Some consider it the first super sedan, a luxury machine with muscle car acceleration and impeccable road manners, all in a stealthy package that looked identical to the six-cylinder versions of the W109 body style. Mercedes aficionados called this Mercedes simply the “six-point-three”.

The heart of the 6.3 was the M100 SOHC V-8 that was first used in the unrivaled Mercedes 600 ultra-luxury sedan introduced in 1963. That car weighed nearly three tons, so putting its 300-horsepower engine into a 3,924-pound package resulted in stunning performance for the time: zero to 60 in seven seconds and a top speed of about 140 mph.

Erich Waxenberger aka Wax'l from Mercedes-Benz came up with the ideal of taking the 6.3 liter engine from the 600 Pulman and put it in the smaller car.  Making the 300 SEL a real German super car.  The 300SEL was faster than the 911, BMWs and was even faster than some of the Ferraris of it's time.  The 6.3 badge on the back of the car had the same appeal as a Hemi badge did on the back of an American car. This car pulls like no other Mercedes-Benz that you'll ever drive.

This is an extremely rare car and there are not many of these for sale in the world.  It has a very nice paint job and a beautiful Cognac Leather interior that is in great condition.  The car drives very well and the air suspension works. Power windows. Air conditioner. Tachometer. 4 Wheel disc brakes. Radio.
The Mercedes-Benz 300SEL 6.3 is one of Jay Leno's favorite cars and for good reasons that are explained in this video.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=3&v=Ct-KlbvGXgo
YOUTUBE VIDEO: https://youtu.be/JwYSMoDibno

1966 MERCEDES-BENZ 250SE
(Stock  3872)
The 2-door, 4-passenger, hardtop coupe has always been a
personal luxury offering by Mercedes-Benz and was priced
near the top of the M.B. line-up. The amazingly elegant ‘111'
style coupe was introduced in 1961 as a “220SE” model with
a fuel-injected, 2.2 litre, straight six cylinder engine. It was
a classically handsome design with a very luxurious leather
interior trimmed in walnut. In 1966, the engine size was
increased to 2.5 litres and the car otherwise remained the
same. Our car was one of these larger-engined cars and was
sold new in Michigan to a woman professor at the
University. She pampered the car for most of its life before
selling it to a close friend following @40 years of ownership.
He, in turn, sold the car to a Mercedes-Benz
collector/enthusiast in New Jersey who is a customer of ours.
Our car is finished in a beautiful deep red with bone leather
and the highly desirable “Tiger Walnut” facia and interior
trim and optional chrome “300SE' fender arches. The car
is equipped with a 4-speed automatic transmission, power
steering, power disc brakes, optional tinted windows and
shaded windshield (helpful should someone wish to have air
conditioning installed) and the original top-of- the-line
Becker “Mexico” AM-FM radio. 95,166 miles. $38,500.
